Mike Woodhouse wrote:

>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>Some other stuff you may not have picked up on. There was some work to
>>break the experiment code into seperate binaries and to attach them at
>>run time with a config file - which in itself may not be that
>>interesting to you, but there is also a mechanism for specifying
>>experimnent prameters such as data file paths within teh config file.
>>    
>>
>
>It doesn't look like you've uploaded that one to SourceForge (or made it
>available or whatever the process is). It's a logical next step, though,
>and I'd definitely find it useful, but don't bust a gut - I've already
>hacked my experiment to take some degree of external configuration, it
>was a logical refactoring.
>  
>

There's a new release (two actually) on sourceforge containing the 
changes. Like you say you probably don't need this now, but it might be 
an idea to cast an eye over the release logs as there are some 
changes/fixes you might be interested in. I've also migrated the project 
files over to .Net 2.0.

I haven' included the zedgraph stuff yet, I'm still not sure about the 
performance and memory footprint. BTW do you know if you can set the 
graphs to roll when the number of data points hits a certain number? 
This was one of the things I managed to do in RudyGraph by using a 
circular buffer based plot set.

>  
>
>>On a more forward looking note, I also started completely revising the
>>whole code base and re-writing it to make it far more flexible to code
>>against 
>>
>
>
>Oooh. I am slightly less terrified by templates/generics than I was,
>having made my first Dictionary, but only slightly. I had to look at
>some template-heavy C++ earlier this week and I'm still feeling the
>effects. I'd be interested in having a look when you've got something
>you're happy with.
>  
>

It's nothing to be scared of. I get the impression that C++ template 
syntax could get a bit cryptic at times, the work I've done so far seems 
pretty straightforward. Anyway more on all that soon I hope.


>[snipped stock model intro]
>
>  
>
>>My initial plan is to use both price and trade volume data.
>>
>You're almost certainly going to need to use derived data rather than
>raw prices: percentage change from day to day is a good start. z-scores
>are good but I'm always slightly concerned that they assume that the
>bounds of the range of source values is known. There are a number of
>other derived values that can be calculated from the technical analysis
>(TA) domain, from the simple (moving averages, relative strength,
>momentum) though trickier (volatility) to the downright exotic
>(Bollinger bands, oscillators, fratal coefficients).
>  
>

I'll probably use percentage change pushed through a sigmoid curve - 
this means I can avoid normalising the range which will of course 
contain some extreme spikes which would cause a problem for a linear 
mapping (normalisation) to the neuron input signal range. I'm going to 
avoid anything too clever and let the network's calculate averages and 
the like for themselves, at least at first.



>In (efficient market) theory, everything that is known about the company
>is encapsulated in the current price. In practice, that turns out not to
>be the case, even if it's just a latency effect. I would think that by
>submitting several days' (months?) worth of basic data you could get a
>model to effectively do its own TA, at the expense of longer compute
>time.
>  
>

Latency is definitely noticeable sometimes, also I've noticed that when 
a price changes very quickly on some piece of news, that the price will 
overshoot the new 'fair' value and bounce around a bit. If you can 
quickly determine (or make an educated guess) what that fair value is 
then you can make money. Drifting off topic here...


>I think that a Neat solution might get some mileage out of the "memory"
>idea I've been playing with: each stock gets a set of values for input
>to the next evaluation that were captured from the previous one.
>  
>

Not sure about this. e.g. it's not like football where your network's 
compete against each other and use memory (potentially) as a sort of 
initial relative rating of two teams. Actually I was wondering if your 
pre-processing is actually providing your networks with information 
about the future, e.g. relative strength of a team determined from 
future results. Or have I misunderstood?

Cheers,


Colin.
